section.title: Introduction to Non-Chord Tones
section.p: Non-chord tonesnon-chord tonesdefinition of are notes that do not belong to the chord. Sometimes referred to as embellishing tones and non-harmonic tones, non-chord tones are classified by how they are approached and left (either by same tone, step, or leap).
There are nine types of non-chord tones.
The following qualifiers can be applied to non-chord tones:

li.p: Unaccentedoccuring on the weak part of the beat (on the offbeat)
Metricalequal to the duration of the beat

section.title: Passing Tones
section.p: Passing tonespassing tone are notes that pass between chord tones.

figure.caption: Desrouleaux, Kirkpatrick, Martin, Robbins, Allan, Want to Want Me

section.p: In the first bar of the Want to Want Me example, the passing tone is unaccented. In the third bar, it is accented (on the beat). The non-chord tone in bar 2 is an appoggiatura.
There can be two consecutive diatonic passing tones in a descending scale segment from the root and fifth of a chord.

figure.caption: Hupfeld, As Time Goes By

idx.h: As Time Goes By (from the motion picture Casablanca)

section.p: Here is an example with chromatic passing tones.

figure.caption: Monk, Blue Monk

section.p: In the next section we discuss the neighbor tone.

section.title: Neighbor Tones
section.p: Neighbor tonesneighbor tone move away from a note by step then return to the note.

figure.caption: Beethoven, Minuet in G, WoO 10, No. 2

section.p: In the next section we discuss the appoggiatura.

section.title: Appoggiatura
section.p: The appoggiaturaappoggiatura is approached by leap and left by step. It is usually accented (on the beat), which makes it a particularly expressive non-chord tone.

figure.caption: Horner and Jennings, My Heart Will Go On

idx.h: My Heart Will Go On (from Titanic)

section.p: The example above also has an anticipation, which is discussed in a later section in this chapter.

figure.caption: Springsteen, Born to Run

section.p: Notice that both the appoggiaturas in the following example resolve up. Both the leap to and step away from any appoggiatura can be from any direction.

figure.caption: Mozart, Symphony No. 40, K. 550, II

section.p: In the next section we discuss the escape tone.

section.title: Escape Tone
section.p: An escape toneescape tone is approached by step and left by leap in the opposite direction. An easy example to remember is the end of the Star-Spangled Banner. The word of in home of the brave is an escape tone.

figure.caption: Francis Scott Key and John Smith, Star-Spangled Banner

section.p: Here is another example, with escape tones used in a melodic sequence.

figure.caption: Joseph Haydn, Piano Sonata in C Major, Hob. XVI:35, III

idx.h: Piano Sonata in C Major, Hob. XVI:35, III

section.p: Here is an example of an escape tone in popular music.

figure.caption: P. McCartney and L. McCartney, Silly Love Songs

section.title: Double Neighbor
section.p: The double neighbordouble neighbor (sometimes called a neighbor groupneighbor group) occurs when both the upper and lower neighbor occur before the return to the starting tone.

figure.caption: C major arpeggio embellished with double neighbors
Friedrich Kuhlau, Sonatina in C Major, Op. 55, No. 1, I

idx.h: Sonatina in C Major, Op. 55, No. 1, I

section.p: The double neighbor is sometimes confused with escape tones and appoggiaturas. Be sure to keep track of chord tones when analyzing non-chord tones. Look at the next example and ask yourself how you would analyze the harmony and non-chord tones on beat 4 of the first measure.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 333, I

section.p: In the next section we discuss the anticipation.

section.title: Anticipation
section.p: An anticipationanticipation is a non-chord tone that anticipates the arrival of the next chord and is often found at cadences, as in the next example.

figure.caption: George Frideric Handel, Rinaldo, Lascia ch'io pianga

section.p: Here is an example of an anticipation in popular music.

figure.caption: Harry and Moroder, Call Me

section.p: Sometimes syncopation will lead to an anticipation of a note in a chord in the following measure, as occurs at the ends of bars 1, 2, and 3 of the Call Me example.

section.title: Pedal Point
section.p: A pedal pointpedal point is a note that is held through changing harmonies, starting as a chord tone before becoming a non-chord tone. Pedal points are often in the bass voice (the term pedal relates to the foot pedals on an organ).

figure.caption: Bach, J.S., Well-Tempered Clavier, Book I, Prelude 1 in C major BWV 846

section.p: Here is an example from the Romantic era.

figure.caption: Clara Schumann, Op. 13, No. 2, Sie liebten sich beide

idx.h: Op. 13, No. 2, Sie liebten sich beide

section.p: The Clara Schumann example above also has a suspension (3-2 sus.); suspensions are discussed in the next section.
When a pedal point is in the bass, it is not necessary to specify the inversion of the chord because the bass pedal point obscures the inversion.
You might also encounter a pedal point in a higher voice, as well as a double pedal point, where two notes (often a fifth apart) act as pedal points.

section.title: Suspension
section.p: Suspensions are accented non-chord tones occurring on downbeats. A suspensionsuspension is approached by the same note and resolves down by step. A suspension is made up of a preparation, suspension, and resolution. Sometimes the preparation is tied to the suspension.

figure.caption: Introductory Suspension example with and without tie

section.p: Suspensions are classified by numbers (9-8, 7-6, 4-3, 2-3, and sometimes 6-5) that specify the interval distance of the suspended note and its resolution to the bass note

figure.caption: Examples of the 9-8, 7-6, 4-3, 2-3, and 6-5 suspensions

section.p: In the example above, the notes in the 4-3 suspension are an 11th and 10th higher than the bass. Reduce all intervals larger than an octave to the numbers 7-6, 4-3, and 6-5.
Here is an example with a 4-3 suspension.

figure.caption: Barber, Adagio for Strings

section.p: Here is an example with 7-6 and 9-8 suspensions.

figure.caption: George Frideric Handel, Suite No. 2 in D Major, HWV 349: II

idx.h: Suite No. 2 in D Major, HWV 349: II

section.p: The 2-3 suspension is the bass suspension and is measured against an upper voice. Again, you may encounter the literal intervals 10-9 but should label the suspension as 2-3.

figure.caption: Bach, J.S., Chorale 238, Liebster Jesu, wir sind hier, BWV 373

idx.h: Chorale 328, Liebster Jesu, wir sind hier, BWV 373

section.p: When a chord is inverted, you will sometimes encounter non-standard suspension numbers like 5-4 or 3-2.

figure.caption: Non-standard suspension numbers because of inverted chords

section.p: You will sometimes encounter decorations of suspensions where other notes occur before the resolution, as in the following example.

figure.caption: Bach, J.S., French Suite No. 1 in D Minor, BWV 812, Sarabande

idx.h: French Suite No. 1 in D Minor, BWV 812, Sarabande

section.p: The ret. in the tenor part in the second measure is a retardation, which is covered in the next section.

section.title: Retardation
section.p: A retardationretardation is usually an accented non-chord tone, meaning it occurs on a downbeat. A retardation is approached by the same note and resolves up by step.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata in C major, K. 545, II

section.p: Classical composers like Mozart often used retardations and suspensions at cadences in slow movements.

section.title: Incomplete Neighbor
section.p: Because composers are notorious for breaking the rules, you will encounter examples in the real world that either defy explanation or have multiple valid explanations. One utility non-chord tone is the incomplete neighbor.

figure.caption: Giacomo Puccini, Gianni Schicchi, O mio babbino caro

idx.h: Gianni Schicchi, O mio babbino caro

section.p: You may also find incomplete double neighbor figures, especially in late Romantic music and jazz. Keep an open mind when analyzing music.

section.title: Adding Non-Chord Tones to a Chord Progression
section.p:
Here are ideas for how to add non-chord tones (or embellishments) to the melody or inner voice part of a chord progression:
Repeated note: add upper or lower neighbor
Step down:
Add a suspension by delaying the resolution of the note
Add an escape tone by moving by step in the opposite direction of the original stepwise movement, then leap
Add a double neighbor
Add a chromatic passing tone
Add an anticipation
Step up:
Add retardation by delaying resolution of the note
Add a double neighbor
Add a chromatic passing tone
Add an anticipation
Add an appoggiatura by leaping one step beyond the note of resolution, placing the appogiatura on the beat, displacing the note of resolution to occur after the beat
Leap of 3rd:
Fill in the 3rd with a passing tone
Add an appoggiatura by leaping one step beyond the note of resolution, placing the appogiatura on the beat, displacing the note of resolution to occur after the beat
Leaps of 4th or larger: do not embellish (for now)
